body_html:
@zheng-xq I managed to solve this issuse.
I happened to run $sudo ldconfig, and the terminal prompted me that 'libcudnn.so' is not a valid symbolic link, although I followed the install instruction step by step.
So I deleted and reinstalled CUDNN in my own way.
At this time, tensorflow works correctly.
Thanks all the same.
Have a nice day.

s = tf.Session()

I tensorflow/core/common_runtime/gpu/gpu_device.cc:755] Creating TensorFlow device (/gpu:0) -> (device: 0, name: GeForce GTX TITAN X, pci bus id: 0000:01:00.0)

I happened to run $sudo ldconfig,  and the terminal prompted  me that 'libcudnn.so' is not a valid symbolic link, although I followed the install instruction step by step.
So I deleted and reinstalled CUDNN in my own way.
At this time, tensorflow works correctly.
Thanks all the same.
Have a nice day.

body:
@zheng-xq I managed to solve this issuse.
I happened to run `$sudo ldconfig`,  and the terminal prompted  me that 'libcudnn.so' is not a valid symbolic link, although I followed the install instruction step by step.
So I deleted and reinstalled CUDNN in my own way.
At this time, tensorflow works correctly.
Thanks all the same.
Have a nice day.
